title: Anvil node stops mining blocks and working after simulating reverted tx
body:
### Component

Anvil

### Have you ensured that all of these are up to date?

- [X] Foundry
- [X] Foundryup

### What version of Foundry are you on?

forge 0.2.0 (c0667c5 2022-05-18T00:16:34.701816Z)

### What command(s) is the bug in?

_No response_

### Operating System

macOS (Intel)

### Describe the bug

All latest, ran `foundryup` about 20 minutes ago:
```
forge 0.2.0 (c0667c5 2022-05-18T00:16:34.701816Z)
cast 0.2.0 (c0667c5 2022-05-18T00:16:34.701816Z)
anvil 0.1.0 (c0667c5 2022-05-18T00:16:35.035292Z)
```

I have some bash scripts which orchestrate a lot of this, but if I call them in the wrong order, anvil seems to break / not let me submit txs / not mine blocks anymore.

Essentially, my workflow which works is:
```
./scripts/node.sh
./scripts/deploy.sh local
./scripts/enable.sh local
```

Apart from reading in env vars and some checks, these scripts basically amount to:
```
anvil -f $MAIN_RPC --chain-id 1
forge create ./src/Contract.sol:Contract i --rpc-url http://localhost:8545 --constructor-args $ARGS --private-key $PRIV_KEY
cast send -i --rpc-url http://localhost:8545 $LOCAL_CONTRACT_ADDRESS "enable()" --private-key $PRIV_KEY
```

Called in this order, they work fine. If I accidentally call them in the order: `node` `enable` `deploy` the entire anvil node breaks and does not accept more requests. Actually, the deploy script does not even work.

Of course, I should not be able to call `enable` on the contract before it is deployed, but still it should not break the node entirely.

It seems that something in anvil gets hung up on the reverting TX `enable`. In the logs I don't even see a reverting TX, I just see
```
eth_sendRawTransaction
```
But of course no output that the tx was successful or unsuccessful.

Trying to deploy then afterwards, nothing shows up in the anvil logs. They just stop but the `anvil` process is still running and `forge create` just hangs.

can't reproduce this with

```
 anvil -f $RPC --chain-id 1
```

```console
cast send --rpc-url http://localhost:8545 $ACCOUNT "enable()" --private-key $PRIV_KEY 
```

succeeds repeatedly

can also deploy after sending

```console
anvil --version
anvil 0.1.0 (c0667c5 2022-05-18T00:16:35.035292Z)
```

perhaps the commands are incomplete?

> Of course, I should not be able to call enable on the contract before it is deployed, but still it should not break the node entirely.

you should be able to call it, but it won't do anything besides charging you for the call

Thanks for the response.

My `node.sh` file is as follows:
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

if [ -f ".env" ]; then
    export $(cat .env | xargs)
else
    echo No .env file found!
    exit 0
fi

# Kill anvil after we exit this script
trap "trap - SIGTERM && kill -- -$$" SIGINT SIGTERM EXIT

anvil -f $MAIN_RPC --chain-id 1 &

sleep 5
cast send --value 1ether $ACCOUNT --private-key 0x59c6995e998f97a5a0044966f0945389dc9e86dae88c7a8412f4603b6b78690d

# Wait for exit command CTRL+C
read -r -d '' _ </dev/tty
```

I know it's a bit janky with the `sleep 5` but I'm not sure of another way to get Ether into the account I want (aside from loading in a mnemoic, which I'd prefer not to do here).

I think it might actually be my frontend / MetaMask hitting the node quite early. Honestly, it's quite flaky for me too and sometimes just restarting anvil fixes it.

If you want, I'm happy to close this issue until I can fully repro this issue because I know it's never fun when you can't easily repro.

Okay, I actually just reproduced it again. So, I ran `./scripts/node.sh` and my cast command never got called.

The anvil output is:
```
Listening on 127.0.0.1:8545
eth_blockNumber
eth_blockNumber
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_chainId
eth_getTransactionCount
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_call
eth_feeHistory
eth_feeHistory
eth_estimateGas
eth_createAccessList
eth_chainId
eth_sendRawTransaction
eth_getTransactionReceipt
eth_blockNumber
```
Then the anvil node doesn't work anymore. It seems to accept RPC requests but never process them.


Without the frontend running right now (but MM still connected to anvil), I get this:
```
eth_blockNumber
eth_chainId
eth_getTransactionCount
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_blockNumber
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_feeHistory
eth_feeHistory
eth_estimateGas
eth_createAccessList
eth_call
eth_sendRawTransaction
eth_getTransactionReceipt

    Transaction: x
    Gas used: 21000
    Block Number: 14801917
    Block Hash: x
    Block Time: "Thu, 19 May 2022 00:29:47 +0000"

eth_blockNumber
eth_getTransactionByHash
eth_getTransactionReceipt

blockHash               x
blockNumber             14801917
contractAddress
cumulativeGasUsed       0
effectiveGasPrice       4000000000
gasUsed                 21000
logs                    []
logsBloom               
root
status                  1
transactionHash         x
transactionIndex        0
type
eth_blockNumber
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_call
eth_blockNumber
```
So, as we can see the cast command works.

Then, with nothing connecting to the anvil node (i.e. no frontend nor MM) I get this:
```
eth_chainId
eth_getTransactionCount
eth_getBlockByNumber
eth_feeHistory
eth_feeHistory
eth_estimateGas
eth_createAccessList
eth_sendRawTransaction
eth_getTransactionReceipt

    Transaction: x
    Gas used: 21000
    Block Number: 14801928
    Block Hash: x
    Block Time: "Thu, 19 May 2022 00:31:46 +0000"


blockHash               x
blockNumber             14801928
contractAddress
cumulativeGasUsed       0
effectiveGasPrice       4000000000
gasUsed                 21000
logs                    []
logsBloom               
root
status                  1
transactionHash         x
transactionIndex        0
type
```
All working as expected.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you can think of anything else for me to check.

I could reproduce this after connecting with metamask

run ./node.sh and immediately open MM

then the first output (above anvil logs) is

```console
Error:
   0: error sending request for url (http://localhost:8545/): error trying to connect: tcp connect error: Connection refused (os error 61)
   1: error trying to connect: tcp connect error: Connection refused (os error 61)
   2: tcp connect error: Connection refused (os error 61)
   3: Connection refused (os error 61)

Location:
   /Users/runner/work/foundry/foundry/cast/src/lib.rs:424

```

which is a cast error, turning anvil logging on (RUST_LOG=backend,rpc) shows that cast fires while the fork state is still being initialized

so what could happen here is that the 5 secs is too short and MM perhaps interferes with the boot process as well.

bumping the sleep timeout seems to resolve the issue.

or perhaps better, reading from stdout and waiting for Listening.

but this makes me think that we need to prioritize getting the server up and running, even before everything is ready so we're able to receive requests instantly

I've updated my `node.sh` script to this anyway:
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

if [ -f ".env" ]; then
    export $(cat .env | xargs)
else
    echo No .env file found!
    exit 0
fi

# Kill anvil after we exit this script
trap "trap - SIGTERM && kill -- -$$" SIGINT SIGTERM EXIT

# Wait for anvil to be listening
exec 3< <(anvil -f $MAIN_RPC --chain-id 1)
sed '/Listening/q' <&3 ; cat <&3 &

cast send --value 1ether $ACCOUNT --private-key 0x59c6995e998f97a5a0044966f0945389dc9e86dae88c7a8412f4603b6b78690d

# Wait for exit command CTRL+C
read -r -d '' _ </dev/tty
```

You're right that it's a better way to do it anyway. But, still it seems an early request into anvil before it's "ready" breaks it.

Thanks for the help on this!

nice!

closing this, feel free to open it again if you discover something weird
